sections.1_story_intuition: Environment and ecology deal with the relationships between living organisms and their surroundings. Understanding these concepts is vital for competitive exams, as questions often focus on conservation, pollution, ecosystems, and sustainable development.
2_key_definitions: Environment: Surroundings in which organisms live.
Ecology: Study of interactions between organisms and their environment.
Ecosystem: Community of living and non-living things interacting together.
Biodiversity: Variety of life forms in an area.
Pollution: Harmful changes in the environment.
Conservation: Protection and management of natural resources.
Sustainable Development: Development meeting present needs without harming future generations.
Greenhouse Effect: Warming of Earth due to trapped heat.
Ozone Layer: Protective layer in the atmosphere.
3_key_facts_data_points: Earth's atmosphere has 78% nitrogen, 21% oxygen.
Biosphere reserves protect biodiversity.
Major greenhouse gases: CO2, methane, nitrous oxide.
Ozone layer absorbs harmful UV rays.
Deforestation leads to soil erosion and loss of habitat.
Chipko Movement was for forest conservation.
Project Tiger started in 1973 to protect tigers.
Ganga Action Plan launched to clean river Ganga.
Noise pollution is measured in decibels (dB).
Renewable resources: Solar, wind, water.
Non-renewable resources: Coal, petroleum, natural gas.
Eutrophication: Excess nutrients in water bodies causing algal bloom.
CFCs damage the ozone layer.
Earth Day is celebrated on April 22.
UNEP: United Nations Environment Programme.
India has 18 biosphere reserves (2025).
Wildlife Protection Act was passed in 1972.
Mangroves protect coastal areas.
Afforestation means planting new trees.
Sustainable development balances economy and environment.
4_micro_notes: Ozone layer protects from UV rays.
5_exam_capsules: What is ecology? Study of organism-environment interactions.
What is biodiversity? Variety of life forms.
What is the greenhouse effect? Trapping of heat by gases.
What is deforestation? Removal of forests.
What is afforestation? Planting new trees.
What is the function of ozone layer? Absorbs UV rays.
What is eutrophication? Algal bloom due to excess nutrients.
What is the Chipko Movement? Forest conservation movement.
What is Project Tiger? Tiger protection program.
What is Ganga Action Plan? River cleaning project.
What is measured in decibels? Noise pollution.
What is a biosphere reserve? Protected biodiversity area.
What is sustainable development? Development without harming future.
7_traps_confusing_points: Mixing up greenhouse effect and ozone depletion.
Mixing up biosphere reserve and wildlife sanctuary.
Assuming all gases are greenhouse gases.
Mixing up CFCs and CO2 effects.

8_case_study_context.title: Chipko Movement
8_case_study_context.explanation: The Chipko Movement was a forest conservation movement in India where villagers hugged trees to prevent their cutting. It raised awareness about the importance of forests and inspired environmental policies.
